revisions.rev:
'''Edin Karamazov''' is a renowned [[Bosnia|Bosnian]] musician-[[lutenist]] (born in 1965 in [[Zenica]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]). He studied lute with [[Hopkinson Smith]] at the [[Schola Cantorum Basiliensis]].
He worked with such ensembles as [[Hesperion]], [[L'Arpeggiata]], [[Hilliard Ensemble]], Mala Punica, [[Orpheus Chamber Orchestra]] and singers [[Andreas Scholl]], [[Maria Cristina Kiehr]], [[Arianna Savall]], and [[Sting (musician)|Sting]].<ref>[http://mixonline.com/recording/projects/audio_sting_edin_karamazov/ Sting With Edin Karamazov]</ref> Karamazov's solo [[archlute]] recording features [[Benjamin Britten]]'s "Nocturnal" and [[J.S.Bach]]'s Partita in d-minor (orig. for violin).
Recent collaborations with Sting (in the field of 16th century music) resulted in the album and film ''[[Songs from the Labyrinth]]'', devoted to the lute-songs of [[John Dowland]].<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wnet/gperf/shows/sting/index.html PBS: Songs from the Labyrinth - Sting and Edin Karamazov]</ref><ref>[http://www.sting.com/news/news.php?uid=6185 Sting & Edin Karamazov perform in February 2009]</ref>
Karamazov's 2008 solo CD project on DECCA "The Lute is a Song" includes guest appearances of [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[RenÃ©e Fleming]] and Macedonian singer and songwriter [[Kaliopi]].<ref>[http://www.stingus.net/sting_the_police_andy_summers_stewart_copeland_news_comments.php?id=6593_0_2_0_C Sting on the solo album "The Lute is a song" of Edin Karamazov]</ref>
